newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela CVG clean-up to cost $250 mln - Poletto.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela CVG clean-up to cost $250 mln - Poletto.

text.p: Cleaning-up environmental damages at Venezuelan state holding company Corporacion Venezolana de Guayana (CVG), slated for a $3 billion privatization later this year, will cost about $250 million, a government minister said.

"There's a $110 million investment we've calculated will be required to ensure future clean production ... but including cleaning-up past damage the total cost will be about $250 million," Venezuelan Investment Fund (FIV) president Alberto Poletto, with portfolio for privatization, told Reuters in an interview.
Most of the environmental liabilities are in the CVG's four company aluminum sector and will be assumed by the new investor once the companies are sold, Poletto said.

As to who would be liable in the future for environmental damages that have not yet made themselves apparent, Poletto said: "There is some very precise language in the sales contract that deals exactly with that."
He did not provide further details.
The future buyer of the aluminum sector, which currently produces around 600,000 metric tonnes per year, will also have to assume the cost of servicing some $1.2 billion in debts.
"The buyer also has to at least maintain current production levels," Poletto said. "Those are the sale conditions."
Thirteen companies have qualified to bid for the four aluminum companies, due to be sold by the end of the year, including Alcoa, Gencor, Alumax, Reynolds Metals Co, Norsk Hydro ASA and RTZ Corp.
